captions.text: The Shamwari Wildlife Rehabilitation Centre
has helped get dozens of animals back to the wild.
Rescuing this calf was the easy part,
the hard part would be getting him to feed.
It was time for Albert the super sheep to make an entrance.
It may not be the warmest of welcomes
but at least Albert’s arrival put a spring in our elephants step.
The sheep does have on its side the fact that it's fast
it can manoeuvre around the elephant.
Our baby finally had something he could chase
and something that was fast enough to escape and not get squashed.
Even so we made sure we had a safe area
for Albert just in case things went wrong.
it was a good spot for him to rest
but only until he got his breath back
and then the chase was on again.
It seemed Albert was just as curious
about his new companion.
It took less than 24 hours
before Themba and Albert where getting along just fine.
They were even taking naps together,
side by side.
It was more than any of us could have hoped for.
I've never seen anything like it
and witnessing that friendship between Themba and Albert was
really special.
I came to realize that elephants weren't just amazing
but sheep also.

title: Sheep and Elephant are Best Friends

comments.author: Adam Ant

comments.text:
+Adam Ant
Potential uses for a partial wing:
1. Mating display
2. Threat display
3. insulating a clutch that is too large to fit under the parent
4. Slowing a fall from high places
5. gliding
6. thermoregulation

Any one or combination of these could have led to the development of 
structures capable of  flight.

Though one is enough, I just thought of 6 off the top of my head.

But lets make this a little more challenging.  How about partial leg? What 
good is partial leg? ... google mudskipper.

An incomplete lung?  google swim bladder.

And NO, evolution does not uniformly give way to the most advantageous 
adaptations. It has no forethought, it doesn't make a plan. Natural 
selection selects for overall phenotypical success.  You don't have to be 
great, just good enough.  And then there is something called genetic drift 
which can totally bugger all in a small population.
comments.author: Animuldok

comments.text:
+Animuldok
Fail.

Okay let's start small for you and I can type slooooowly if you need.

*Let's start with Birds.*

I'll let you take the first stab at it.

But here's the premise.

*Evolution gives way to the most advantageous adaptions.*

Explain how a Wing evolved.

For thousands... maybe millions of years, a bird would have a partially 
formed wing.

*Clearly a disadvantage.*

Go....!
comments.author: Adam Ant

comments.text:
+Adam Ant You failed. I at no time said a theory could ever be a fact (read 
my last sentence of the previous post).  There is a theory of Evolution and 
the fact of the observation we call evolution.  They are intimately 
related, but not the same.

In all my years of study, I was never force-fed the theory of evolution.  
In fact, if a formal theory was never offered to me i can say that I would 
have come to the same basic conclusions early in my biology education.  As 
with all theories, it will always be revised as more information becomes 
available.  But the basic tenets of the theory are sound.

Incidentally, what does your IQ or method in which it was determined have 
anything to do with the theory of evolution.  Would it make any difference 
if it was 90 or 190?

And, discussing "Darwinian Evolution" is similar to discussing "Mendelian 
Genetics" and "Newtonian Gravity."  Each has its place, but all have been 
improved upon.
comments.author: Animuldok

comments.text:
+Animuldok
You jump too quickly to say a theory is fact.

*There are many holes in the Darwinian Theory of Evolution.*

Let me make something clear, *I believe things Evolve.*

We can observe evolution on a microbiological level very quickly.

What I am saying is that the *leading theory of Darwinian Evolution* is 
akin to the *Flat Earth Theory.*

There is simply *too much evidence* showing the Theory we are being force 
fed is incomplete and inaccurate.

Incidentally, my I.Q. is 158 tested over 5 years  in a clinical study. [Not 
some bullshit online test.]
comments.author: Adam Ant

comments.text:
+Adam Ant
I am a veterinarian (DVM) with a BS in Biology.  My IQ has been measured 
twice (152 and 157).  It is obvious your education has been lacking in the 
field of biology.
See human Chromosome #2 
Well supported  theories are more useful that facts.  They make falsifiable 
predictions.
Evolution is a fact:
We can objectively observe that allelic frequencies in reproductive 
populations change over time.
Evolution is a theory:
The process of evolution (the change in allelic frequencies within a 
reproductive population over time) results in the biodiversity we see now 
and the fossil record of extinct and intermediate species.

Your incompetence at understanding a scientific theory Vs. fact is at the 
root of your ignorance.  A theory NEVER "graduates" to become a fact.
comments.author: Animuldok

comments.text:
+selimate
I have one query for you.

Give it your best shot.

please insert your hands into a wood chipper until you can no longer
